ุงููุตู ุงูุฎุงูุณุ ูู ุณูุงู ุงูุญุฏูุซ ุนู ูุดููุฉ ุงูุจุญุซ ูู ุงูุนุงูู ุงูุตุบูุฑ)ุ ูุน ูุนุงูููู: ุฏูููุฏ ูููุจู ูุฅููุง ุชุงุฑุฏูุณุ ุจุญุซูุง ุซูุฑูููุง ุนู ูุดุฑ ุณูุงุณู

ูููููุง ูู ุงูููุงูุฉ. 

[1mูุฑุงุกุงุช ุฅุถุงููุฉ [0m

The following pages are designed as a guide for readers who want to expand their understanding of the science of networks, start 
doing their own research, or simply learn some more details about the topics mentioned in the book. As such, the readings are 
coded by difficulty, according to the simple rating scale given below. Also, the readings are broken down by chapter and section, 
thus enabling a quick association between specific topics and the relevant material. A complete, alphabetized bibliography 
follows. As long as the reading list is, it is far from comprehensive. In fact, most subjects have been covered rather sparsely, 
if at all, and I apologize to any authors that I have erroneously excluded. Such obvious omissions notwithstanding, it remains the 
case that by starting here, the uninitiated reader can quickly find much of the major literature associated with the new science 
of networks. And a lot more besides. 

[1mุฏุฑุฌุงุช ุงูุตุนูุจุฉ [0m

โ [1mBeginner [0m(no more difficult than this book). 

โโ [1mIntermediate [0m(some effort and mathematical background required). 

โข [1mAdvanced [0m(requires undergraduate-level mathematics training). 

โขโข [1mExpert [0m(impenetrable without graduate-level mathematics training). 

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุฃูู: ุนุตุฑูุง ุงููุชุดุงุจู [0m

The proximate causes and immediate effects of the cascading failure that occurred in the Western Systems Coordinating Council 
transmission grid on August 10, 1996, are described in: 

โ WSCC Operations Committee. [3mWestern Systems Coordinating Council Disturbance Report, August 10, 1996 [0m(October 18, 1996). 
Available on-line at http://www.wscc.com/outages.htm. 

A review of major recent power disturbances in the United States that sheds some additional light on the August 10 cascade is: 

โ Hauer, J. F., and Dagel, J. E. [3mWhite Paper on Review of Recent Reliability Issues and System Events. [0mConsortium for Electric 
Reliability Technology Solutions. U.S. Department of Energy (1999). Available on-line at 
http://www.eren.doe.gov/der/transmission/pdfs/reliabilityevents.pdf. 

Some theoretical papers dealing with the problem of cascading failures in power transmission networks are: 

โโ Kosterev, D. N., Taylor, C. W., and Mittelstadt, W. A. Model validation for the August 10, 1996 WSCC system outage. [3mIEEE 
Transactions on Power Systems, [0m14(3), 967โ979 (1999). 

โข Sachtjen, M. L., Carreras, B. A., and Lynch, V. E. Disturbances in a power transmission system. [3mPhysical Review E, [0m61(5), 
4877โ4882 (2000). 

โขโข Asavathiratham, C. The influence model: A tractable representation for the dynamics of networked Markov chains (Ph.D. 
dissertation, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, MIT, 2000). 

[1m(ูก) ุงููุดูุก [0m

Although the author doesnโt call it emergence, one of the earliest works to really grapple with the issue of emergent behavior in 
complex (social) systems is: 

โ Schelling, T. C. [3mMicromotives and Macrobehavior [0m(Norton, New York, 1978). 

The classic paper by Phillip Anderson that outlines the fundamental concept of emergence is: 

โโ Anderson, P. W. More is different. [3mScience, [0m177, 393โ396 (1972). 

Some very readable introductions to the subject of complex, adaptive systems in general, and emergence in particular, are: 

โ Gell-Mann, M. [3mThe Quark and the Jaguar: Adventures in the Simple and the Complex [0m(W. H. Freeman, New York, 1994). 

โ Holland, J. H. [3mHidden Order: How Adaptation Builds Complexity [0m(Perseus, Cambridge, MA, 1996). 

โ Waldrop, M. M. [3mComplexity: The Emerging Science at the Edge of Order and Chaos [0m(Touchstone, New York, 1992). 

A more technical read is: 

โข Casti, J. L. [3mReality Rules I & II: Picturing the World in Mathematics: The Fundamentals, the Frontier [0m(Wiley-Interscience, New 
York, 1997). 

[1m(ูข) ุงูุดุจูุงุช [0m

A good introduction to the mathematical theory of graphs (and one that explains Eulerโs theorem in detail) is: 

โโ West, D. B. [3mIntroduction to Graph Theory [0m(Prentice-Hall, Upper Saddle River, NJ, 1996). 

A more applied approach to the subject, focusing more on algorithms and applications than on theorems, is presented in the 
following general texts: 

โโ Lynch, N. A. [3mDistributed Algorithms [0m(Morgan Kauffman, San Francisco, 1997). 

โโ Ahuja, R. K., Magnanti, T. L., and Orlin, J. B. [3mNetwork Flows: Theory, Algorithms, and Applications [0m(Prentice-Hall, Englewood 
Cliffs, NJ, 1993). 

โขโข Nagurney, A. [3mNetwork Economics: A Variational Inequality Approach [0m(Kluwer Academic, Boston, 1993). 

[1m(ูฃ) ุงููุฒุงููุฉ [0m

The best way to learn about the subject of coupled oscillators is from Steve Strogatz himself in his recent book: 

โ Strogatz, S. H. [3mSync: The Emerging Science of Spontaneous Order [0m(Hyperion, Los Angeles, 2003). 

Strogatz has also written two shorter accounts of his (and related) work on the Kuramoto model: 

โข Strogatz, S. H. Norbert Wienerโs brain waves. In Levin, S. A. (ed.), [3mFrontiers in Mathematical Biology, Lecture Notes in 
Biomathematics, 100 [0m(Springer, New York, 1994), pp. 122โ138. 

โ Strogatz, S. H., and Stewart, I. Coupled oscillators and biological synchronization. [3mScientific American, [0m269(6), 102โ109 
(1993). 

[1m(ูค) ุงูุทุฑูู ุงูุฃูู ุงุฑุชูุงุฏูุง [0m

Winfreeโs original paper on the entrainment of coupled oscillators that kicked off much of the recent literature, and that was my 
initial reference point, is: 

โข Winfree, A. T. Biological rhythms and the behavior of populations of coupled oscillators. [3mJournal of Theoretical Biology, [0m16, 
15โ42 (1967). 

For those who want to learn more from the master, a fascinating (albeit a somewhat challenging) read is: 

โข Winfree, A. T. [3mThe Geometry of Biological Time [0m(Springer, Berlin, 1990). 

[1m(ูฅ) ูุณุฃูุฉ ุงูุนุงูู ุงูุตุบูุฑ [0m

The famous [3mPsychology Today [0mpaper that everyone cites when they talk about Milgramโs work is: 

โ Milgram, S. The small world problem. [3mPsychology Today, [0m2, 60โ67 (1967). 

A better reference, however, is a paper that Milgram published two years later with his graduate student, Jeffrey Travers. It 
contains considerably more detail than the [3mPsychology Today [0marticle, and although it isnโt quite as fun, it is actually much 
clearer. 

โ Travers, J., and Milgram, S. An experimental study of the small world problem. [3mSociometry, [0m32(4), 425โ443 (1969). 

The very first study of the small-world problem was by Manfred Kochen and Ithiel de Sola Pool, who circulated their results as a 
working paper almost ten years before Milgram conducted his experiment. In fact, it was this paper that stimulated Milgramโs work 
in the first place. It was finally published, almost twenty years after its inception, as the first paper in the first volume of 
the journal [3mSocial Networks [0m. 

โโ Pool, I. de Sola, and Kochen, M. Contacts and influence. [3mSocial Networks, [0m1(1), 1โ51 (1978). 

A number of subsequent papers, both theoretical and empirical, as well as the original paper by Kochen and Pool, are available in 
a collected volume, edited by Manfred Kochen. 

โโ Kochen, M. (ed.). [3mThe Small World [0m(Ablex, Norwood, NJ, 1989). 

The play by John Guare that was later made into a movie, and launched the phrase โsix degrees of separationโ into the pop-culture 
stratosphere, is: 

โ Guare, J. [3mSix Degrees of Separation: [0mA Play (Vintage Books, New York, 1990). 

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุซุงูู: ุฃุตูู ุนูู ยซุฌุฏูุฏยป [0m

[1m(ูก) ูุธุฑูุฉ ุงูุฑุณูู ุงูุจูุงููุฉ ุงูุนุดูุงุฆูุฉ [0m

Random-graph theory is not for the faint of heart. As a result, there are not really any readings one might call โaccessible.โ 
Nevertheless, here are some important ones. The original results of Erdลs and Rรฉnyi dealing with the evolution and connectedness 
of random graphs are contained in the following series of classic papers (none of which are easy to find in your average library): 

โขโข Erdลs, P., and Rรฉnyi, A. On random graphs. [3mPublicationes Mathematicae, [0m6, 290โ297 (1959). 

โขโข Erdลs, P., and Rรฉnyi, A. On the evolution of random graphs. [3mPublications of the Mathematical Institute of the Hungarian Academy 
of Sciences, [0m5, 17โ61 (1960). 

โขโข Erdลs, P., and Rรฉnyi, A. On the strength and connectedness of a random graph. [3mActa Mathematica Scientia Hungary, [0m12, 261โ267 
(1961). 

The standard textbook for the field of random graphs, and one that summarizes the most significant developments since Erdลs and 
Rรฉnyi, is: 

โขโข [3mBollobas, B. Random Graphs, [0m2d ed. (Academic, New York, 2001). 

A slightly more readable (although not as comprehensive) treatment of the subject is: 

โข Alon, N., and Spencer, J. H. [3mThe Probabilistic Method [0m(Wiley-Interscience, New York, 1992). 

[1m(ูข) ุงูุดุจูุงุช ุงูุงุฌุชูุงุนูุฉ [0m

The standard textbook for social network analysis is: 

โโ Wasserman, S., and Faust, K. [3mSocial Network Analysis: Methods and Applications [0m(Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1994). 

Two shorter, less comprehensive, but more readable alternatives are: 

โโ Degenne, A., and Forse, M. [3mIntroducing Social Networks [0m(Sage, London, 1999). 

โโ Scott, A. [3mSocial Network Analysis, [0m2d ed. (Sage, London, 2000). 

Finally, a very short collection of classic papersโthe ones that introduced some of the central concepts in the fieldโincludes: 

โโ Boorman, S. A., and White, H. C. Social structure from multiple networks. II. Role structures. [3mAmerican Journal of Sociology, [0m
81(6), 1384โ1446 (1976). 

โโ Burt, R. S. [3mStructural Holes: The Social Structure of Competition [0m(Harvard University Press, Cambridge, MA, 1992). 

โโ Davis, J. A. Structural balance, mechanical solidarity, and interpersonal relations. [3mAmerican Journal of Sociology, [0m68(4), 
444โ462 (1963). 

โโ Freeman, L. C. A set of measures of centrality based on betweenness. [3mSociometry, [0m40, 35โ41 (1977). 

โโ Granovetter, M. S. The strength of weak ties. [3mAmerican Journal of Sociology, [0m78, 1360โ1380 (1973). 

โโ Harary, F. Graph theoretic measures in the management sciences. [3mManagement Science, [0m5, 387โ403 (1959). 

โขโข Holland, P. W., and Leinhardt, S. An exponential family of probability distributions for directed graphs. [3mJournal of the 
American Statistical Association, [0m76, 33โ65 (1981). 

โโ Lorrain, F., and White, H. C. Structural equivalence of individuals in social networks. [3mJournal of Mathematical Sociology, [0m1, 
49โ80 (1971). 

โขโข Pattison, P. [3mAlgebraic Models for Social Networks [0m(Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1993). 

โโ White, H. C., Boorman, S. A., and Breiger, R. L. Social structure from multiple networks. I. Blockmodels of roles and 
positions. [3mAmerican Journal of Sociology, [0m81(4), 730โ780 (1976). 

[1m(ูฃ) ููุฏููุงููููุงุช ุฃูููุฉ [0m

Because the subject of networks and dynamics is such a new one, there is really no text on the subject. One starting place is the 
following edited volumeโa collection of roughly forty papers with introductions written by the editors: 

โขโข Newman, M. E. J., Barabรกsi, A. L., and Watts, D. J. [3mThe Structure and Dynamics of Networks [0m(Princeton University Press, 
Princeton, NJ, 2003). 

A great introduction to the field of nonlinear dynamics is: 

โโ Strogatz, S. H. [3mNonlinear Dynamics and Chaos with Applications to Physics, Biology, Chemistry, and Engineering [0m(Addison-Wesley, 
Reading, MA, 1994). 

And a discussion of its relevance to networks is: 

โโ Strogatz, S. H. Exploring complex networks. [3mNature, [0m410, 268โ275 (2001). 

A paper that points out the limitations of centrality as a surrogate for social influence is: 

โโ Mizruchi, M. S., and Potts, B. B. Centrality and power revisited: Actor success in group decision making. [3mSocial Networks, [0m20, 
353โ387 (1998). 

The story quoting Jon Kleinberg on the connection to Bill Gates is: 

โ Wildavsky, B. Small world, isnโt it? [3mU.S. News and World Report, April [0m1, 2002, p. 68. 

And the article that suggested OTPOR as a good example of decentralized action is: 

โ Cohen, R. Who really brought down Milosevic? [3mNew York Times Magazine, [0mNovember 26, 2000, p. 43. 

[1m(ูค) ุงูุงุจุชุนุงุฏ ุนู ุงูุนุดูุงุฆูุฉ [0m

Over a period of more than a decade, Anatol Rapoport produced a series of papers that laid out the theory of random-biased nets. 
The central ideas, however, are contained in the following pair of papers: 

โข Solomonoff, R., and Rapoport, A. Connectivity of random nets. [3mBulletin of Mathematical Biophysics, [0m13, 107โ117 (1951). 

โข Rapoport, A. A contribution to the theory of random and biased nets. [3mBulletin of Mathematical Biophysics, [0m19, 257โ271 (1957). 

A summary of the random-biased network approach is given in: 

โข Rapoport, A. Mathematical models of social interaction. In Luce, R. D., Bush, R. R., and Galanter, E. (eds.), [3mHandbook of 
Mathematical Psychology, [0mvol. 2 (Wiley, New York, 1963), pp. 493โ579. 

Rapoportโs own account of his life, and his lifeโs work, is: 

โ Rapoport, A. [3mCertainties and Doubts: A Philosophy of Life [0m(Black Rose Press, Montreal, 2000). 

[1m(ูฅ) ุฏูุฑ ุงูููุฒูุงุฆููู [0m

The classic text on the theory of critical phenomena is: 

โข Stanley, H. E. [3mIntroduction to Phase Transitions and Critical Phenomena [0m(Oxford University Press, Oxford, 1971). 

A more contemporary version is: 

โข Sornette, D. [3mCritical Phenomena in Natural Sciences [0m(Springer, Berlin, 2000). 

A detailed discussion of spin systems and phase transitions is given in: 

โข Palmer, R. Broken ergodicity. In Stein, D. L. (ed.), [3mLectures in the Sciences of Complexity, [0mvol. I, Santa Fe Institute Studies 
in the Sciences of Complexity (Addison-Wesley, Reading, MA, 1989), pp. 275โ300. 

โข Stein, D. L. Disordered systems: Mostly spin systems. In Stein, D. L. (ed.), [3mLectures in the Sciences of Complexity, [0mvol. I, 
Santa Fe Institute Studies in the Sciences of Complexity (Addison-Wesley, Reading, MA, 1989), pp. 301โ354. 

If one actually wants to do work in this field, a useful text is: 

โข Newman, M. E. J., and Barkema, G. T. [3mMonte Carlo Methods for Statistical Physics [0m(Clarendon Press, Oxford, 1999). 

And finally, a very accessible text that uses simple computer models to explain many of the central concepts of nonlinear dynamics 
and critical phenomena is: 

โโ Flake, G. W. [3mThe Computational Beauty of Nature: Computer Explorations of Fractals, Chaos, Complex Systems, and Adaptation [0m(MIT 
Press, Cambridge, MA, 1998). 

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุซุงูุซ: ุนูุงูู ุตุบูุฑุฉ [0m

The original account of my work with Steve Strogatz was my Ph.D. dissertation, later published as: 

โโ Watts, D. J. [3mSmall Worlds: The Dynamics of Networks between Order and Randomness [0m(Princeton University Press, Princeton, NJ, 
1999). 

[1m(ูก) ูุณุงุนุฏุฉ ุจุณูุทุฉ ูู ุงูุฃุตุฏูุงุก [0m

A discussion of [3magency, [0mas the term is understood by sociologists, is: 

โ Emirbayer, M., and Mische, A. What is agency? [3mAmerican Journal of Sociology, [0m103(4), 962โ1023 (1998). 

The computer algorithms used to do the relevant calculations are quite standard and can be learned from any good text on 
algorithms. Two good examples are: 

โโ Aho, A. V., Hopcroft, J. E., and Ullman, J. D. [3mData Structures and Algorithms [0m(Addison-Wesley, Reading, MA, 1983). 

โโ Ahuja, R. K., Magnanti, T. L., and Orlin, J. B. [3mNetwork Flows: Theory, Algorithms, and Applications [0m(Prentice-Hall, Englewood 
Cliffs, NJ, 1993). 

[1m(ูข) ูู ุณูุงู ุงููููู ุฅูู ุฃูุงูู ุณููุงุฑูุง [0m

The two books from Asimovโs [3mRobot [0mseries that inspired my discussion with Steve are: 

โ Asimov, I. [3mThe Caves of Steel [0m(Doubleday, Garden City, NY, 1954). 

โ Asimov, I. [3mThe Naked Sun [0m(Doubleday, Garden City, NY, 1957). 

[1m(ูฃ) ุนูุงูู ุตุบูุฑุฉ [0m

The derivation of the alpha model, and the consequent identification of small-world networks, are presented in: 

โโ Watts, D. J. Networks, dynamics and the small-world phenomenon. [3mAmerican Journal of Sociology, [0m105(2), 493โ527 (1999). 

A simpler, but similar, version of the model was later studied by: 

โข Jin, E. M., Girvan, M., and Newman, M. E. J. The structure of growing networks. [3mPhysical Review E, [0m64, 046132 (2001). 

[1m(ูค) ุจุณูุท ูุฏุฑ ุงููุณุชุทุงุน [0m

The beta model and the empirical results about small-world networks were first published in: 

โโ Watts, D. J., and Strogatz, S. H. Collective dynamics of โsmall-worldโ networks. [3mNature, [0m393, 440โ442 (1998). 

Subsequent work on the beta model, and even simpler related models, includes: 

โข Barthelemy, M., and Amaral, L. A. N. Small-world networks: Evidence for a crossover picture. [3mPhysical Review Letters, [0m82, 
3180โ3183 (1999). 

โขโข Monasson, R. Diffusion, localization and dispersion relations on โsmall-worldโ lattices. [3mEuropean Physical Journal B, [0m12(4), 
555โ567 (1999). 

โข Newman, M. E. J., and Watts, D. J. Scaling and percolation in the small-world network model. [3mPhysical Review E, 60, [0m7332โ7342 
(1999). 

โข Newman, M. E. J., and Watts, D. J. Renormalization group analysis of the small-world network model. [3mPhysics Letters A, [0m263, 
341โ346 (1999). 

โข Newman, M. E. J., Moore, C., and Watts, D. J. Mean-field solution of the small-world network model. [3mPhysical Review Letters, [0m84, 
3201โ3204 (2000). 

Much of this early work is reviewed in: 

โข Newman, M. E. J. Models of the small world. [3mJournal of Statistical Physics, [0m101, 819โ841 (2000). 

[1m(ูฅ) ุงูุนุงูู ุงููุงูุนู [0m

In addition to exploring the theoretical properties of small-world networks, researchers have identified a wide variety of 
empirical cases. Some examples are: 

โโ Adamic, L. A. The small world web. [3mIn Lecture Notes in Computer Science, [0m1696, [3mProceedings of the European Conference in 
Digital Libraries (ECDL) โ99 Conference [0m(Springer, Berlin, 1999), pp. 443โ454. 

โ Davis, G. F., Yoo, M., and Baker, W. E. The small world of corporate elite (working paper, University of Michigan Business 
School, 2002). 

โโ Ferrer i Cancho, R., Janssen, C., and Solรฉ, R. V. Topology of technology graphs: Small world patterns in electronic circuits. [3m
Physical Review E, [0m64, 046119 (2001). 

โ Kogut, B., and Walker, G. The small world of Germany and the durability of national networks. [3mAmerican Sociological Review, [0m
66(3), 317โ335 (2001). 

โโ Sporns, O., Tononi, G., and Edelman, G. M. Theoretical neuroanatomy: Relating anatomical and functional connectivity in graphs 
and cortical connection matrices. [3mCerebral Cortex, [0m10, 127โ141 (2000). 

โโ Wagner, A., and Fell, D. The small world inside large metabolic networks. [3mProceedings of the Royal Society of London, Series B, [0m
268, 1803โ1810 (2001). 

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุฑุงุจุน: ูุง ูุฑุงุก ุงูุนุงูู ุงูุตุบูุฑ [0m

[1m(ูก) ุงูุดุจูุงุช ุนุฏููุฉ ุงููุนูุงุฑ [0m

A highly accessible account of the science of networks that focuses on the development and importance of scale-free networks is: 

โ Barabรกsi, A. L. [3mLinked: The New Science of Networks [0m(Perseus Press, Cambridge, MA, 2002). 

Some more mathematical treatments of random networks with non-Poisson degree distributions (including power-law distributions) can 
be found in: 

โขโข Aiello, W., Chung, F., and Lu, L. A random graph model for massive graphs. In [3mProceedings of the 32nd Annual ACM Symposium on 
the Theory of Computing [0m(Association for Computing Machinery, New York, 2000), pp. 171โ180. 

โขโข Molloy, M., and Reed, B. A critical point for random graphs with a given degree sequence. [3mRandom Structures and Algorithms, [0m6, 
161โ179 (1995). 

โขโข Molloy, M., and Reed, B. The size of the giant component of a random graph with a given degree sequence. [3mCombinatorics, 
Probability, and Computing, [0m7, 295โ305 (1998). 

โขโข Newman, M. E. J., Strogatz, S. H., and Watts, D. J. Random graphs with arbitrary degree distributions and their applications. [3m
Physical Review E, [0m64, 026118 (2001). 

[1m(ูข) ุงูุฃุซุฑูุงุก ูุฒุฏุงุฏูู ุซุฑุงุก [0m

The paper by Lรกszlรณ Barabรกsi and Rรฉka Albert that introduced the idea of scale-free networks, and proposed a preferential 
attachment model of network growth to account for them, is: 

โโ Barabรกsi, A., and Albert, R. Emergence of scaling in random networks. [3mScience, [0m286, 509โ512 (1999). 

Since Barabรกsi and Albertโs original paper, a great many papers have been written on the subject of scale-free networks. Many of 
the references and relevant results are summarized in: 

โข Albert, R., and Barabรกsi, A. L. Statistical mechanics of complex networks. [3mReview of Modern Physics, [0m74, 47โ97 (2002). 

Oddly enough, the original discovery of scale-free networks predates Lรกszlรณ Barabรกsi and Rรฉka Albertโs paper by over thirty years. 
The empirical observation that networks can have a power-law degree distribution was first presented by Derek de Solla Price in: 

โโ Price, D. J. de Solla. Networks of scientific papers. [3mScience, [0m149, 510โ515 (1965). 

Eleven years later, Price proposed a mathematical model that was, in essence, identical to that of Barabรกsi and Albertโs. Given 
how popular the notion of scale-free networks has become, one might wonder why no one picked up on it at the time. Perhaps the 
title (and the journal) had something to do with it. 

โโ Price, D. J. de Solla. A general theory of bibliometrics and other cumulative advantage processes. [3mJournal of the American 
Society of Information Science, [0m27, 292โ306 (1976). 

Continuing on an historical note, Zipfโs law was first proposed in: 

โโ Zipf, G. K. [3mHuman Behavior and the Principle of Least Effort [0m(Addison-Wesley, Cambridge, MA, 1949). 

And Herbert Simon first presented the idea of preferential, random growth as an explanation of power-law size distributions like 
Zipfโs law in: 

โข Simon, H. A. On a class of skew distribution functions. [3mBiometrika, [0m42, 425โ440 (1955). 

The article was reprinted two decades later, along with a significant amount of subsequent and related work, in: 

โข Ijiri, Y., and Simon, H. A. [3mSkew Distributions and the Sizes of Business Firms [0m(Elsevier/North-Holland, New York, 1977). 

Finally, the notion of the Matthew effect in the context of scientific prestige was introduced by Robert K. Merton in: 

โ Merton, R. K. The Matthew effect in science. [3mScience, [0m159, 56โ63 (1968). 

[1m(ูฃ) ุชุญููู ุงูุซุฑุงุก ูููู ุฃู ูููู ุนุณูุฑูุง [0m

Empirical evidence (mostly) for and (occasionally) against the prevalence of scale-free networks has appeared in a number of 
places. Some of the more interesting papers are as follows: 

โโ Amaral, L. A. N., Scala, A., Barthelemy, M., and Stanley, H. E. Classes of behavior of small-world networks. [3mProceedings of the 
National Academy of Sciences, [0m97, 11149โ11152 (2000). 

โโ Adamic, L. A., and Huberman, B. A. Power-law distribution of the World Wide Web. [3mScience, [0m287, 2115a (2000). 

โโ Barabรกsi, A. L., Albert, R., Jeong, H., and Bianconi, G. Power-law distribution of the World Wide Web, [3mScience, [0m287, 2115b 
(2000). 

โโ Faloutsos, M., Faloutsos, P., and Faloutsos, C. On power-law relationships of the Internet topology. [3mComputer Communication 
Review, [0m29, 251โ262 (1999). 

โโ Liljeros, F., Edling, C. R., Amaral, L. A. N., Stanley, H. E., and Aberg, Y. The web of human sexual contacts. [3mNature, [0m411, 
907โ908 (2001). 

โข Rapoport, A. Mathematical models of social interaction. In Luce, R. D., Bush, R. R., and Galanter, E. (eds.), [3mHandbook of 
Mathematical Psychology, [0mVol. 2 (Wiley, New York, 1963), pp. 493โ579. 

โโ Redner, S. How popular is your paper? An empirical study of the citation distribution. [3mEurophysics Journal B, [0m4, 131โ134 
(1998). 

[1m(ูค) ุฅุนุงุฏุฉ ุชูุฏูู ุจููุฉ ุงููุฌููุนุงุช [0m

The paper Harrison presented that triggered our work on affiliation networks is: 

โ White, H. C. What is the center of the small world? (paper presented at American Association for the Advancement of Science 
annual symposium, Washington, D.C., February 17โ22, 2000). 

And two classic references dealing with the importance of groups to the structure of social networks are: 

โโ Nadel, F. S. [3mTheory of Social Structure [0m(Free Press, Glencoe, IL, 1957). 

โโ Breiger, R. L. The duality of persons and groups. [3mSocial Forces, [0m53, 181โ190 (1974). 

[1m(ูฅ) ุดุจูุงุช ุงูุงุฑุชุจุงุท [0m

A good basic reference for affiliation networks is: 

โโ Wasserman, S., and Faust, K. [3mSocial Network Analysis: Methods and Applications [0m(Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1994). 

[1m(ูฆ) ุงููุฏูุฑูู ูุงูุนููุงุก [0m

Jerry Davisโs work on interlocking boards of corporate directors is presented in: 

โ Davis, G. F. The significance of board interlocks for corporate governance. [3mCorporate Governance, [0m4(3), 154โ159 (1996). 

โ Davis, G. F., and Greve, H. R. Corporate elite networks and governance changes in the 1980s. [3mAmerican Journal of Sociology, [0m
103(1), 1โ37 (1997). 

And Mark Newmanโs data on collaboration networks of scientists is: 

โโ Newman, M. E. J. The structure of scientific collaboration networks. [3mProceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, [0m98, 
404โ409 (2001). 

Or in (slightly exhausting) detail: 

โโ Newman, M. E. J. Scientific collaboration networks: I. Network construction and fundamental results. [3mPhysical Review E, 64, [0m
016131 (2001). 

โโ Newman, M. E. J. Scientific collaboration networks: II. Shortest paths, weighted networks, and centrality. [3mPhysical Review E, 
64, [0m016132 (2001). 

[1m(ูง) ุชุนููุฏุงุช [0m

The mathematical machinery used to analyze the affiliation networks is described in: 

โขโข Newman, M. E. J., Strogatz, S. H., and Watts, D. J. Random graphs with arbitrary degree distributions and their applications. [3m
Physical Review E, [0m64, 026118 (2001). 

And a slightly more readable version is: 

โข Newman, M. E. J., Watts, D. J., and Strogatz, S. H. Random graph models of social networks. [3mProceedings of the National Academy 
of Sciences, [0m99, 2566โ2572 (2002). 

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุฎุงูุณ: ุงูุจุญุซ ูู ุงูุดุจูุงุช [0m

A compendium of Milgramโs research over his entire, fascinating career is: 

โ Milgram, S. [3mThe Individual in a Social World: Essays and Experiments, [0m2d ed. (McGraw-Hill, New York, 1992). 

A detailed description of his obedience experiments is in: 

โ Milgram, S. [3mObedience to Authority: An Experimental View [0m(Harper & Row, New York, 1974). 

[1m(ูก) ูุง ุงูุฐู ุฃูุถุญู ูููุฌุฑุงู ุญูููุงุ [0m

Judith Kleinfeldโs paper that exams the history and empirical validity of the small-world problem is: 

โ Kleinfeld, J. S. The small world problem. [3mSociety, [0m39(2), 61โ66 (2002). 

The most significant follow-up study to the original experiment is one that Milgram conducted with another student, Charles Korte, 
in which they attempted to connect a white population of senders in Los Angeles with white and African-American targets in New 
York: 

โ Korte, C., and Milgram, S. Acquaintance networks between racial groupsโapplication of the small world method. [3mJournal of 
Personality and Social Psychology, [0m15(2), 101 (1970). 

[1m(ูข) ูู ุงูุฑูู ุณุชุฉ ูุจูุฑ ุฃู ุตุบูุฑุ [0m

The problem of Erdลs numbers has been studied extensively by the mathematician Jerry Grossman, who maintains a Web page on the 
subject at http://www.oakland.edu/~grossman/erdoshp.html. An early summary of his work is: 

โโ Grossman, J. W., and Ion, P. D. F. On a portion of the well-known collaboration graph. [3mCongressus Numerantium, [0m108, 129โ131 
(1995). 

Some more recent work on Erdลs numbers is by: 

โโ Batagelj, V., and Mrvar, A. Some analyses of Erdลs collaboration graph. [3mSocial Networks, [0m22(2), 173โ186 (2000). 

Other evidence that small-world networks can make problem-solving harder, rather than easier, is presented in: 

โข Walsh, T. Search in a small world. In [3mProceedings of the 16th International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence [0m(Morgan 
Kaufmann, San Francisco 1999), pp. 1172โ1177. 

[1m(ูฃ) ูุดููุฉ ุงูุจุญุซ ูู ูุณุฃูุฉ ุงูุนุงูู ุงูุตุบูุฑ [0m

Jon Kleinbergโs groundbreaking paper, which pointed out and then solved the small-world search problem, is available in two 
versions, long and short, respectively: 

โข Kleinberg, J. The small-world phenomenon: An algorithmic perspective. In [3mProceedings of the 32nd Annual ACM Symposium on Theory 
of Computing [0m(Association of Computing Machinery, New York, 2000), pp. 163โ170. 

โโ Kleinberg, J. Navigation in a small world. [3mNature, [0m406, 845 (2000). 

Kleinberg later used a similar approach to study the spread of information in networks via what computer scientists call a [3mgossip 
protocol: [0m

โข Kleinberg, J. Small-world phenomena and the dynamics of information. In Dietterich, T. G., Becker, S., and Ghahramani, Z. 
(eds.), [3mAdvances in Neural Information Processing Systems [0m(NIPS), 14 (MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, 2002). 

[1m(ูค) ุฑุฏ ุนูู ุงูุงุฌุชูุงุน [0m

The paper that resulted from my collaboration with Mark Newman and Peter Dodds, incorporating notions of social identity and 
social distance into the small-world search problem, is: 

โโ Watts, D. J., Dodds, P. S., and Newman, M. E. J. Identity and search in social networks. [3mScience, [0m296, 1302โ1305 (2002). 

The findings of the so-called reverse small-world experiment that corroborated some of our theoretical predictions were published 
in: 

โโ Killworth, P. D., and Bernard, H. R. The reverse small world experiment. [3mSocial Networks, [0m1, 159โ192 (1978). 

โ Bernard, H. R., Killworth, P. D., Evans, M. J., McCarty, C., and Shelly, G. A. Studying relations cross-culturally. [3mEthnology, [0m
27(2), 155โ179 (1988). 

[1m(ูฅ) ุงูุจุญุซ ูู ุดุจูุงุช ุงููุฏ ูููุฏ [0m

A discussion of the problems facing peer-to-peer networks like Gnutella is: 

โโ Ritter, J. P. Why Gnutella canโt scale. No really (working paper, available on-line at 
http://www.darkridge.com/~jpr5/doc/gnutella.html, 2000). 

Two search algorithms that take advantage of Gnutellaโs apparent scale-free character are presented in: 

โข Adamic, L. A., Lukose, R. M., Puniyani, A. R., and Huberman, B. A. Search in power-law networks. [3mPhysical Review E, [0m64, 046135 
(2001). 

โข Kim, B. J., Yoon, C. N., Han, S. K., and Jeong, H. Path finding strategies in scale-free networks. [3mPhysical Review E, [0m65, 027103 
(2002). 

And a discussion of the problems associated with creating easily searchable distributed databases in the context of a 
multinational consulting firm is: 

โ Mannville, B. Complex adaptive knowledge management: A case study from McKinsey and Company. In Clippinger, J. H. (ed.), [3mThe 
Biology of Business: Decoding the Natural Laws of the Enterprise [0m(Jossey-Bass, San Francisco, 1999), chapter 5. 

Some other approaches that have been proposed specifically for the purpose of finding information on the World Wide Web are dealt 
with in the following: 

โโ Brin, S., and Page, L. The anatomy of a large-scale hypertextual web search engine. [3mComputer Networks, [0m30, 107โ117 (1998). 

โข Gibson, D., Kleinberg, J., and Raghavan, P. Inferring Web communities from link topology. In [3mProceedings of the 9th ACM 
Conference on Hypertext and Hypermedia [0m(Association for Computing Machinery, Networks 1998), pp. 225โ234. 

โข Kleinberg, J. Authoritative sources in a hyperlinked environment. [3mJournal of the ACM, [0m46, 604โ632 (1999). 

โโ Lawrence, S., and Giles, C. L. Accessibility of information on the web. [3mNature, [0m400, 107โ109 (1999). 

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุณุงุฏุณ: ุงูุฃูุจุฆุฉ ูุงูุฃุนุทุงู [0m

[1m(ูก) ุงูููุทูุฉ ุงูุญุงุฑุฉ [0m

Richard Prestonโs gripping account of the Ebola outbreak in Reston, Virginia, along with a brief history of Ebola, can be found in 
his book: 

โ Preston, R. [3mThe Hot Zone [0m(Random House, New York, 1994). 

Additional Ebola facts were derived from: 

โ Harden, B. Dr. Matthewโs passion. [3mNew York Times Magazine, [0mFebruary 18, 2001, pp. 24โ62. 

[1m(ูข) ููุฑูุณุงุช ุงูุฅูุชุฑูุช [0m

The account of the e-mail sent by Claire Swire was taken from a [3mNew York Times [0marticle: 

โ Lyall, S. Return to sender, please. [3mNew York Times, [0mDecember 24, 2000, [3mWeek in Review, [0mp. 2. 

A chronology of the Melissa virus can be found at http://www.cert.org/ advisories/CA-1999-04.html. 

Records of all registered computer viruses and their histories, including time of first detection, known number of computers 
infected, and first release of antiviral software, can be found at the Virus Bulletin: http://www.virusbtn.com/. Virus alerts, 
along with other Internet-related security information, are published and maintained by CERT, based in the Software Engineering 
Institute at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh. Their Web site is http://www.cert.org/. 

A discussion of the relationship between epidemiology and computer viruses in the age of the Internet is contained in the 
following: 

โข Kephart, J. O., White, S. R., and Chess, D. M. Computer viruses and epidemiology. [3mIEEE Spectrum, [0m30(5), 20โ26 (1993). 

โโ Kephart, J. O., Sorkin, G. B., Chess, D. M., and White, S. R. Fighting computer viruses. [3mScientific American, [0m277(5), 56โ61 
(1997). 

[1m(ูฃ) ุฑูุงุถูุงุช ุงูุฃูุจุฆุฉ [0m

The classic papers of Kermack and McKendrick, on which most of modern mathematical epidemiology is based, are: 

โขโข Kermack, W. O., and McKendrick, A. G. A contribution to the mathematical theory of epidemics. [3mProceedings of the Royal Society 
of London, Series A, [0m115, 700โ721 (1927). 

โขโข Kermack, W. O., and McKendrick, A. G. Contributions to the mathematical theory of epidemics. II. The problem of endemicity. [3m
Proceedings of the Royal Society of London, Series A, [0m138, 55โ83 (1932). 

โขโข Kermack, W. O., and McKendrick, A. G. Contributions to the mathematical theory of epidemics. III. Further studies of the 
problem of endemicity. [3mProceedings of the Royal Society of London, Series A, [0m141, 94โ122 (1933). 

The standard text of mathematical epidemiology, and one that treats the SIR model in considerable detail, is: 

โข Bailey, N. T. J. [3mThe Mathematical Theory of Infectious Diseases and Its Applications [0m(Hafner Press, New York, 1975). 

Other good references are: 

โข Bartholomew, D. J. [3mStochastic Models for Social Processes [0m(Wiley, New York, 1967). 

โข Anderson, R. M., and May, R. M. [3mInfectious Diseases of Humans [0m(Oxford University Press, Oxford, 1991). 

โข Murray, J. D. [3mMathematical Biology, [0m2d ed. (Springer, Heidelberg, 1993). 

A small but excellent collection of papers dealing with the spread of infectious diseases on networks is: 

โขโข Ball, F., Mollison, D., and Scalia-Tomba, G. Epidemics with two levels of mixing. [3mAnnals of Applied Probability, [0m7(1), 46โ89 
(1997). 

โโ Hess, G. Disease in metapopulation models: Implications for conservation. [3mEcology, [0m77, 1617โ1632 (1996). 

โโ Kareiva, P. Population dynamics in spatially complex environments: Theory and data. [3mPhilosophical Transactions of the Royal 
Society of London, Series B, [0m330, 175โ190 (1988). 

โข Kretschmar, M., and Morris, M. Measures of concurrency in networks and the spread of infectious disease. [3mMathematical 
Biosciences, [0m133, 165โ195 (1996). 

โโ Longini, I. M., Jr. A mathematical model for predicting the geographic spread of new infectious agents. [3mMathematical 
Biosciences, [0m90, 367โ383 (1988). 

โข Sattenspiel, L., and Simon, C. P. The spread and persistence of infectious diseases in structured populations. [3mMathematical 
Biosciences, [0m90, 341โ366 (1988). 

[1m(ูค) ุงูุฃูุจุฆุฉ ูู ุนุงูู ุตุบูุฑ [0m

The most complete account of the early work on disease spreading on small-world networks is chapter 6 of: 

โโ Watts, D. J. [3mSmall Worlds: The Dynamics of Networks between Order and Randomness [0m(Princeton University Press, Princeton, NJ, 
1999). 

A number of subsequent results about epidemics on networks have been published in the following papers: 

โข Boots, M., and A. Sasaki. โSmall worldsโ and the evolution of virulence: Infection occurs locally and at a distance. [3mProceedings 
of the Royal Society of London, Series B, [0m266, 1933โ1938 (1999). 

โข Keeling, M. J. The effects of local spatial structure on epidemiological invasions. [3mProceedings of the Royal Society of London, 
Series B, [0m266, 859โ867 (1999). 

โข Kuperman, M., and Abramson, G. Small world effect in an epidemiological model. [3mPhysical Review Letters, [0m86, 2909โ2912 (2001). 

Some excellent works on the foot-and-mouth epidemic, and a fine example of mathematical modeling contributing to policy decisions, 
are: 

โโ Ferguson, N. M., Donnelly, C. A., and Anderson, R. M. The foot-and-mouth epidemic in Great Britain: Pattern of spread and 
impact of interventions. [3mScience, [0m292, 1155โ1160 (2001). 

โโ Ferguson, N. M., Donnelly, C. A., and Anderson, R. M. Transmission intensity and impact of control policies on the foot and 
mouth epidemic in Great Britain. [3mNature, [0m413, 542โ548 (2001). 

โโ Keeling, M. J., Woolhouse, M. E. J., Shaw, D. J., Matthews, L., Chase-Topping, M., Haydon, D. T., Cornell, S. J., Kappey, J., 
Wilesmith, J., and Grenfell, B. T. Dynamics of the 2001 UK foot and mouth epidemic: Stochastic dispersal in a heterogeneous 
landscape. [3mScience, [0m294, 813โ817 (2001). 

The discovery that diseases spreading in scale-free networks donโt exhibit an epidemic threshold is reported in: 

โข Pastor-Satorras, R., and Vespignani, A. Epidemic spreading in scale-free networks. [3mPhysical Review Letters, [0m86, 3200โ3203 
(2001). 

Pastor-Satorras and Vespignani have continued to work on disease spreading in scale-free networks. Their findings are summarized 
in: 

โข Pastor-Satorras, R., and Vespignani, A. Epidemics and immunization in scale-free networks. In Bornholdt, S., and Schuster, H. G. 
(eds.), [3mHandbook of Graphs and Networks: From the Genome to the Internet [0m(Wiley-VCH, Berlin, 2002). 

Some empirical support for their assumption of a scale-free e-mail network is reported in: 

โข Ebel, H., Mielsch, L. I., and Bornholdt, S. Scale-free topology of e-mail networks. [3mPhysical Review E, [0m66, 035103 (2002). 

The public health impact of needle exchange programs is analyzed in a report for the [3mJournal of the American Medical Association [0m
by the Center for AIDS Prevention Studies, University of California, San Francisco, found at 
http://www.ama-assn.org/special/hiv/preventn/prevent3.htm. 

An earlier report prepared for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention can be found at 
http://www.caps.ucsf.edu/capsweb/publications/ needlereport.html. 

[1m(ูฅ) ููุงุฐุฌ ุงูุชุฎูู ููุฃูุฑุงุถ [0m

The best introduction to the subject of percolation is the following (which even manages to be funny in places): 

โข Stauffer, D., and Aharony, A. [3mIntroduction to Percolation Theory [0m(Taylor and Francis, London, 1992). 

The details of my work with Mark Newman on a site percolation approach to disease spreading on small-world network are given in: 

โข Newman, M. E. J., and Watts, D. J. Scaling and percolation in the small-world network model. [3mPhysical Review E, [0m60, 7332โ7342 
(1999). 

[1m(ูฆ) ุงูุดุจูุงุช ูุงูููุฑูุณุงุช ููุงููุฑูุณููุช [0m

Mark Newman and Cris Mooreโs work on site and bond percolation is described in the following: 

โข Moore, C., and Newman, M. E. J. Epidemics and percolation in small-world networks. [3mPhysical Review E, [0m61, 5678โ5682 (2000). 

โขโข Moore, C., and Newman, M. E. J. Exact solution of site and bond percolation on small-world networks. [3mPhysical Review E, [0m62, 
7059โ7064 (2000). 

[1m(ูง) ุงูุฃุนุทุงู ูุงูููุฉ [0m

The original paper using percolation ideas to quantify network robustness is: 

โโ Albert, R., Jeong, H., and Barabรกsi, A. L. Attack and error tolerance of complex networks. [3mNature, [0m406, 378โ382 (2000). 

Soon after, a series of papers examined the topic in greater detail. They are: 

โข Callaway, D. S., Newman, M. E. J., Strogatz, S. H., and Watts, D. J. Network robustness and fragility: Percolation on random 
graphs. [3mPhysical Review Letters, [0m85, 5468โ5471 (2000). 

โข Cohen, R., Erez, K., ben-Avraham, D., and Havlin, S. Resilience of the Internet to random breakdowns. [3mPhysical Review Letters, [0m
85, 4626โ4628 (2000). 

โข Cohen, R., Erez, K., ben-Avraham, D., and Havlin, S. Breakdown of the Internet under intentional attack. [3mPhysical Review 
Letters, [0m86, 3682โ3685 (2001). 

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุณุงุจุน: ุงููุฑุงุฑุงุช ูุงูุฃููุงู ูุฌููู ุงูุฌูุงููุฑ [0m

[1m(ูก) ุงูุชุตุงุฏูุงุช ุงูุชููููุจ [0m

Charles Mackayโs classic account of mania, financial and otherwise, has been reprinted many times. A relatively recent version is: 

โ Mackay, C. [3mExtraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds [0m(Harmony Books, New York, 1980). 

Some other recent treatises on the same subject are: 

โ Kindleberger, C. P. [3mManias, Panics, and Crashes: A History of Financial Crises, [0m4th ed. (Wiley, New York, 2000). 

โ Shiller, R. J. Irrational Exuberance (Princeton University Press, Princeton, NJ, 2000). 

[1m(ูข) ุงูุฎูู ูุงูุทูุน ูุงูุนููุงููุฉ [0m

Adam Smithโs discussion of rationally optimizing agents, including his reference to the invisible hand, is in: 

โ Smith, A. [3mThe Wealth of Nations, [0mVol. 1, Book 4 (University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 1976), chapter 2, p. 477. 

The paradox of the efficient market hypothesis is described in: 

โ Chancellor, E. [3mDevil Take the Hindmost: A History of Financial Speculation [0m(Farrar, Straus and Giroux, New York, 1999). 

And some recent work on constructing a more realistic vision of both investor and financial-market behavior, in which dynamics is 
a crucial ingredient, is: 

โข Farmer, J. D. Market force, ecology, and evolution. [3mIndustrial and Corporate Change, [0mforthcoming (2002). 

โข Farmer, J. D., and Joshi, S. The price dynamics of common trading strategies. [3mJournal of Economic Behavior and Organization, [0m
49(2), 149โ171 (2002). 

โโ Farmer, J. D., and Lo, A. Frontiers of finance: Evolution and efficient markets. [3mProceedings of the National Academy of 
Sciences, [0m96, 9991-9992 (1999). 

[1m(ูฃ) ุงููุฑุงุฑุงุช ุงูุฌูุนูุฉ [0m

The technical paper by Natalie Glance and Bernardo Huberman, describing the dinerโs dilemma and the conditions under which it can 
be resolved, is: 

โข Glance, N. S., and Huberman, B. A. The outbreak of cooperation. [3mJournal of Mathematical Sociology, [0m17(4), 281โ302 (1993). 

A more accessible description of the same results is: 

โ Glance, N. S., and Huberman, B. A. The dynamics of social dilemmas. [3mScientific American, [0m270(3), 76โ81 (1994). 

The literature on the evolution of cooperation is gigantic and spans several disciplinesโevolutionary biology, economics, 
political science, and sociology in particular. It is impossible even to provide a representative list of publications, but some 
important contributions are: 

โโ Axelrod, R. [3mThe Evolution of Cooperation [0m(Basic Books, New York, 1984). 

โโ Axelrod, R., and Dion, D. The further evolution of cooperation. [3mScience, [0m242, 1385โ1390 (1988). 

โข Boorman, S. A., and Levitt, P. R. [3mThe Genetics of Altruism [0m(Academic Press, New York, 1980). 

โโ Boyd, R. S., and Richerson, P. J. The evolution of reciprocity in sizable groups. [3mJournal of Theoretical Biology, [0m132, 337โ356 
(1988). 

โโ Hardin, G. The tragedy of the commons. [3mScience, [0m162, 1243โ1248 (1968). 

โโ Huberman, B. A., and Lukose, R. M. Social dilemmas and Internet congestion. [3mScience, [0m277, 535โ537 (1997). 

โโ Nowak, M. A., and May, R. M. Evolutionary games and spatial chaos. [3mNature, [0m359, 826โ829 (1992). 

โโ Olson, M. [3mThe Logic of Collective Action: Public Goods and the Theory of Groups [0m(Harvard University Press, Cambridge, MA, 
1965). 

โ Ostrom, E., Burger, J., Field, C. B., Norgaard, R. B., and Policansky, D. Revisiting the commons: Local lessons, global 
challenges. [3mScience, [0m284, 278โ282 (1999). 

[1m(ูค) ุณูุงุณู ุงููุนูููุงุช [0m

The literature on information cascades is, again, multidisciplinary and eclectic. Some examples are: 

โโ Aguirre, B. E., Quarantelli, E. L., and Mendoza, J. L. The collective behavior of fads: The characteristics, effects, and 
career of streaking. [3mAmerican Sociological Review, [0m53, 569โ584 (1988). 

โข Banerjee, A. V. A simple model of herd behavior. [3mQuarterly Journal of Economics, [0m107, 797โ817 (1992). 

โข Bikhchandani, S., Hirshleifer, D., and Welch, I. A theory of fads, fashion, custom and cultural change as informational 
cascades. [3mJournal of Political Economy, [0m100(5), 992โ1026 (1992). 

โโ Lohmann, S. The dynamics of informational cascades: The Monday demonstrations in Leipzig, East Germany, 1989โ91. [3mWorld 
Politics, [0m47, 42โ101 (1994). 

[1m(ูฅ) ูุคุซุฑุงุช ุงููุนูููุงุช ุงูุฎุงุฑุฌูุฉ [0m

A description of Aschโs original experiment is given in: 

โ Asch, S. E. Effects of group pressure upon the modification and distortion of judgments. In Cartwright, D., and Zander, A. 
(eds.), [3mGroup Dynamics: Research and Theory [0m(Row, Peterson, Evanston, IL, 1953), pp. 151โ162. 

Herbert Simonโs theory of bounded rationality is espoused in: 

โโ Simon, H. A., Egidi, M., and Marris, R. L. [3mEconomics, Bounded Rationality and the Cognitive Revolution [0m(Edward Elgar, 
Brookfield, VT, 1992). 

[1m(ูฆ) ุงููุคุซุฑุงุช ุงูุฎุงุฑุฌูุฉ ุงููุณุฑูุฉ [0m

The spread of crime via a network of peer pressure relationships is considered (in a theoretical manner) in: 

โโ Glaeser, E. L., Sacerdote, B., and Schheinkman, J. A. Crime and social interactions. [3mQuarterly Journal of Economics, [0m111, 
507โ548 (1996). 

The paper introducing the concept of a spiral of silence in voting behavior is: 

โ Noelle-Neumann, E. Turbulences in the climate of opinion: Methodological applications of the spiral of silence theory. [3mPublic 
Opinion Quarterly, [0m41(2), 143โ158 (1977). 

[1m(ูง) ูุคุซุฑุงุช ุงูุณูู ุงูุฎุงุฑุฌูุฉ [0m

The principal exponent of what is now called lock-in via increasing returns is the economist Brian Arthur. His groundbreaking 
paper (which took him many years to find a journal that would publish it) is: 

โข Arthur, W. B. Competing technologies, increasing returns, and lock-in by historical events. [3mEconomic Journal, [0m99(394), 116โ131 
(1989). 

Another, slightly different, approach to the topic of increasing returns is espoused in: 

โข Romer, P. Increasing returns and long-run growth. [3mJournal of Political Economy, [0m94(5), 1002โ1034 (1986). 

Although the authors do not link it to the subject of network externalities, the importance of complementarities is emphasized in: 

โข Milgrom, P., and Roberts, J. The economics of modern manufacturing: Technology, strategy, and organization. [3mAmerican Economic 
Review, [0m80(3), 511โ528 (1990). 

Meanwhile, the prevailing economics approach to so-called network externalities is described in: 

โโ Economides, N. The economics of networks. [3mInternational Journal of Industrial Organization, [0m16(4), 673โ699 (1996). 

[1m(ูจ) ูุคุซุฑุงุช ุงูุชูุณูู ุงูุฎุงุฑุฌูุฉ [0m

Although neither of these papers uses the term, the relevance of externalities to decisions about cooperation is evident in: 

โข Glance, N. S., and Huberman, B. A. The outbreak of cooperation. [3mJournal of Mathematical Sociology, [0m17(4), 281โ302 (1993). 

โโ Kim, H., and Bearman, P. The structure and dynamics of movement participation. [3mAmerican Sociological Review, [0m62(1), 70โ94 
(1997). 

[1m(ูฉ) ุตูุงุนุฉ ุงููุฑุงุฑ ุงุฌุชูุงุนูููุง [0m

The report on body piercing is: 

โ Harden, B. Coming to grips with the enduring appeal of body piercing. [3mNew York Times, [0mFebruary 12, 2002, p. A16. 

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุซุงูู: ุงูุญุฏูุฏ ูุงูุณูุงุณู ููุงุจููุฉ ุงูุชูุจุค [0m

[1m(ูก) ููุงุฐุฌ ุญุฏูุฏ ุงููุฑุงุฑุงุช [0m

The earliest use of threshold models as a way of understanding collective decision making is probably: 

โโ Schelling, T. C. A study of binary choices with externalities. [3mJournal of Conflict Resolution, [0m17(3), 381โ428 (1973). 

Another early classic is: 

โโ Granovetter, M. Threshold models of collective behavior. [3mAmerican Journal of Sociology, [0m83(6), 1420โ1443 (1978). 

The actual derivation of a threshold model depends on what kind of decision an individual is making, and what sort of decision 
externalities pertain. Some examples of quite different derivations, all of which effectively generate threshold rules are: 

โข Arthur, W. B., and Lane, D. A. Information contagion. [3mStructural Change and Economic Dynamics, [0m4(1), 81โ103 (1993). 

โข Boorman, S. A., and Levitt, P. R. [3mThe Genetics of Altruism [0m(Academic Press, New York, 1980). 

โข Durlauf, S. N. A framework for the study of individual behavior and social interactions. [3mSociological Methodology, [0m31, 47โ87 
(2001). 

โข Glance, N. S., and Huberman, B. A. The outbreak of cooperation. [3mJournal of Mathematical Sociology, [0m17(4), 281โ302 (1993). 

โข Morris, S. N. Contagion. [3mReview of Economic Studies, [0m67, 57โ78 (2000). 

[1m(ูฃ) ุงูุณูุงุณู ูู ุงูุดุจูุงุช ุงูุงุฌุชูุงุนูุฉ [0m

Some information about [3mIthaca hours [0mcan be found in: 

โ Glover, P. Grassroots economics. [3mIn Context, [0m41, 30 (1995). 

โ Morse, M. Dollars or sense. [3mUtne Reader, [0m99 (SeptemberโOctober 1999). 

Everett Rogersโ classic reference on the diffusion of innovations, in which much of the still-current terminology was introduced, 
was first published in 1962. It is now in its fourth edition: 

โ Rogers, E. [3mThe Diffusion of Innovations, [0m4th ed. (Free Press, New York, 1995). 

A valiant attempt to combine Rogersโ ideas with concepts from social network analysis is by one of Rogersโ students, Thomas 
Valente: 

โโ Valente, T. W. [3mNetwork Models of the Diffusion of Innovations [0m(Hampton Press, Cresskill, NJ, 1995). 

โ Coleman, J. S., Katz, E., and Menzel, H. The diffusion of an innovation among physicians. [3mSociometry, [0m20(4), 253โ270 (1957). 

[1m(ูค) ุงูุณูุงุณู ูุงูุชุฎูู [0m

The paper summarizing the threshold model approach to information cascades on networks is: 

โข Watts, D. J. A simple model of global cascades on random networks. [3mProceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, [0m99, 
5766โ5771 (2002). 

[1m(ูฅ) ุงูุชุญููุงุช ุงูุทูุฑูุฉ ูุงูุณูุงุณู [0m

Malcolm Gladwellโs engaging discussion of social contagion is: 

โ Gladwell, M. [3mThe Tipping Point: How Little Things Can Make a Big Difference [0m(Little, Brown, New York, 2000). 

[1m(ูฆ) ุชุฌุงูุฒ ุงูุตุฏุน [0m

Geoffrey Mooreโs descriptive account of the โchasmโ between early adopters and the early to late majority is given in: 

โ Moore, G. A. [3mCrossing the Chasm: Marketing and Selling High-Tech Products to Mainstream Customers [0m(Harper Business, New York, 
1999). 

[1m(ูง) ูุฌูุฉ ูุธุฑ ุบูุฑ ุฎุทูุฉ ููุชุงุฑูุฎ [0m

The distinction between quality and success is made apparent in Art De Vanyโs study of the movie industry: 

โโ De Vany, A., and Lee, C. Quality signals in information cascades and the dynamics of motion picture box office revenues: A 
computational model. [3mJournal of Economic Dynamics and Control, [0m25, 593โ614 (2001). 

โข De Vany, A. S., and Walls, W. D. Bose-Einstein dynamics and adaptive contracting in the motion picture industry. [3mEconomic 
Journal, [0m106, 1493โ1514 (1996). 

[1m(ูฉ) ุนูุฏุฉ ุฅูู ุงูููุฉ [0m

The related notions of normal accidents and robust-yet-fragile systems are presented in two very different works: 

โ Perrow, C. [3mNormal Accidents: Living with High-Risk Technologies [0m(Basic Books, New York, 1984). 

โข Carlson, J. M., and Doyle, J. Highly optimized tolerance: A mechanism for power laws in designed systems. [3mPhysical Review E, [0m
60(2), 1412โ1427 (1999). 

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุชุงุณุน: ุงูุงุจุชูุงุฑ ูุงูุชููููู ูุงูุชุนุงูู [0m

[1m(ูก) ุฃุฒูุฉ ุชูููุชุง-ุขูุณูู [0m

The account of the Toyota-Aisin crisis on which my description is based is: 

โ Nishiguchi, T., and Beaudet, A. Fractal design: Self-organizing links in supply chain management. In Von Krogh, G., Nonaka, I., 
and Nishiguchi, T. (eds.), [3mKnowledge Creation: A Source of Value [0m(Macmillan, London, 2000). 

Another paper about the remarkable Toyota group that guided our thinking on innovation is: 

โ Ward, A., Liker, J. K., Cristiano, J. J., and Sobek, D. K. The second Toyota paradox: How delaying decisions can make better 
cars faster. [3mSloan Management Review, [0m36(3), 43โ51 (1995). 

[1m(ูข) ุงูุฃุณูุงู ูุงูููุงูู ุงููุฑููุฉ [0m

The original textโand still one of the greatestโon industrial organization is: 

โ Smith, A. [3mThe Wealth of Nations [0m(University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 1976). 

A precursor to Coaseโs theory of transaction costs was Frank Knightโs claim that firms exist to reduce uncertainty: 

โโ Knight, F. H. [3mRisk, Uncertainty, and Profit [0m(London School of Economics and Political Science, London, 1933). 

And Ronald Coaseโs original argument of transaction costs as the basis for the firm is explicated in: 

โ Coase, R. The nature of the firm. [3mEconomica, [0mn.s., 4 (November 1937). 

Several decades later, Coase is still trying to get his ideas accepted by mainstream economics. His latest attempt is: 

โ Coase, R. [3mThe Nature of the Firm [0m(Oxford University Press, Oxford, 1991). 

The chief proponent of the hierarchical structure of firms is Oliver Williamson, whose views are expressed comprehensively in: 

โโ Williamson, O. [3mE. Markets and Hierarchies [0m(Free Press, New York, 1975). 

A shorter version is: 

โโ Williamson, O. E. Transaction cost economics and organization theory. In Smelser, N. J., and Swedberg, R. (eds.), [3mThe Handbook 
of Economic Sociology [0m(Princeton University Press, Princeton, NJ, 1994), pp. 77โ107. 

The superiority of the hierarchy has been extensively formalized and developed in recent years by a small group of economists, led 
by Roy Radner. Some of the principal works of this literature are: 

โข Bolton, P., and Dewatripont, M. The firm as a communication network. [3mQuarterly Journal of Economics, [0m109(4), 809โ839 (1994). 

โข Radner, R. The organization of decentralized information processing. [3mEconometrica, [0m61(5), 1109โ1146 (1993). 

โข Radner, R. Bounded rationality, indeterminacy, and the theory of the firm. [3mEconomic Journal, [0m106, 1360โ1373 (1996). 

โข Van Zandt, T. Decentralized information processing in the theory of organizations. In Sertel, M. (ed.), [3mContemporary Economic 
Issues, [0mvol. 4: [3mEconomic Design and Behavior [0mp. 125โ160 (Macmillan, London, 1999), chapter 7. 

[1m(ูฃ) ุงูุชูุณููุงุช ุงูุตูุงุนูุฉ [0m

Michael Piore and Chuck Sabelโs groundbreaking book on the changing nature of the global economy is: 

โ Piore, M. J., and Sabel, C. F. [3mThe Second Industrial Divide: Possibilities for Prosperity [0m(Basic Books, New York, 1984). 

[1m(ูค) ุงูุบููุถ [0m

The paper describing Hondaโs system for identifying problems in their manufacturing plants is: 

โ MacDuffie, J. P. The road to โroot causeโ: Shop-floor problemsolving at three auto assembly plants. [3mManagement Science, [0m43, 4 
(1997). 

A variety of approaches to the theory of the internal architecture of the firm have been taken within the economics, sociology, 
and business communities. It is a vast literature. An eclectic collection of readings, with no claim to being exhaustive or even 
representative, is as follows: 

โ Chandler, A. D. [3mThe Visible Hand: The Managerial Revolution in American Business [0m(Belknap Press of Harvard University Press, 
Cambridge, MA, 1977). 

โ Clippinger, J. (ed.). [3mThe Biology of Business: Decoding the Natural Laws of the Enterprise [0m(Jossey-Bass, San Francisco, 1999). 

โข Fama, E. F. Agency problems and the theory of the firm. [3mJournal of Political Economy, [0m88, 288โ307 (1980). 

โโ Hart, O. [3mFirms, Contracts and Financial Structure [0m(Oxford University Press, New York, 1995). 

โโ March, J. G., and Simon, H. A. [3mOrganizations [0m(Blackwell, Oxford, 1993). 

โโ Nelson, R. R., and Winter, S. G. [3mAn Evolutionary Theory of Economic Change [0m(Belknap Press of Harvard University Press, 
Cambridge, MA, 1982). 

โโ Powell, W., and DiMaggio, P. (eds.). [3mThe New Institutionalism in Organizational Analysis [0m(Chicago, University of Chicago Press, 
1991). 

โข Sah, R. K., and Stiglitz, J. E. The architecture of economic systems: Hierarchies and polyarchies. [3mAmerican Economic Review, [0m
76(4), 716โ727 (1986). 

[1m(ูฅ) ุงูุทุฑููุฉ ุงูุซุงูุซุฉ [0m

An indication of Chuckโs understanding of the problem at the time we started working together is given in the following: 

โ Helper, S., MacDuffie, J. P., and Sabel, C. F. Pragmatic collaborations: Advancing knowledge while controlling opportunism. [3m
Industrial and Corporate Change, [0m9(3), 443โ488 (2000). 

โ Sabel, C. F. Diversity, not specialization: The ties that bind the (new) industrial district. In Quadrio Curzio, A., and Fortis, 
M. (eds.), [3mComplexity and Industrial Clusters: Dynamics and Models in Theory and Practice [0m(Physica-Verlag, Heidelberg, 2002). 

[1m(ูฆ) ุงูุชููู ูุน ุงูุบููุถ [0m

Perhaps the clearest exposition of the conundrum faced by firms in ambiguous environments, and their need to be both adapted and 
adaptable, is that by David Stark in his work on [3mheterarchies [0m: 

โ Stark, D. C. Recombinant property in East European capitalism. [3mAmerican Journal of Sociology, [0m101(4), 993โ1027 (1996).

โ Stark, D. C., and Bruszt, L. [3mPostsocialist Pathways: Transforming Politics and Property in East Central Europe [0m(Cambridge 
University Press, Cambridge, 1998). 

[1m(ูง) ุงูุดุจูุงุช ูุชุนุฏุฏุฉ ุงููุณุชููุงุช [0m

The properties of team-based, multiscale, and core-periphery networks are outlined in: 

โข Dodds, P. S., Watts, D. J., and Sabel, C. F. The structure of optimal redistribution networks. Institute for Social and Economic 
Research and Policy Working Paper, Columbia University (2002). 

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุนุงุดุฑ: ููุงูุฉ ุงูุจุฏุงูุฉ [0m

The use of New York City (or more precisely, the borough of Manhattan) as an example of a complex system was inspired by John 
Hollandโs opening chapter in: 

โ Holland, J. H. [3mHidden Order: How Adaptation Builds Complexity [0m(Perseus, Cambridge, MA, 1996). 

[1m(ูก) ุงูุญุงุฏู ุนุดุฑ ูู ุณุจุชูุจุฑ [0m

An excellent and detailed account of the September 11 attacks on the World Trade Center, and the monumental recovery effort that 
followed its collapse, is given in: 

โ Langewiesche, W. [3mAmerican Ground: Unbuilding the World Trade Center [0m(North Point Press, New York, 2002). 

The information about the police departmentโs communications predicament was derived from: 

โ Rashbaum, W. K. Police officers swiftly show inventiveness during crisis. [3mNew York Times, [0mSeptember 17, 2001, p. A7. 

The story about Cantor Fitzgerald was related by one of the survivorsโthe director of marketing and communicationsโwho spoke at a 
roundtable discussion of business leaders at Columbia University on December 5, 2001. The roundtable was organized by David Stark 
and John Kelly, directors of Columbiaโs Center for Organizational Innovation and Interactive Design Lab, respectively, and 
sponsored by Dr. Susan Gitelson. 

The article by Paul Krugman considering the economic consequences of the September 11 attacks in the context of an already 
faltering economy is: 

โ Krugman, P. Fear itself. [3mNew York Times Magazine, [0mSeptember 30, 2001, p. 36. 

[1m(ูข) ุฏุฑูุณ ูุนุตุฑ ูุชุดุงุจู [0m

An engaging and insightful account of the 1997 Asian crisis is contained in: 

โ Friedman, T. L. [3mThe Lexus and the Olive Tree: Understanding Globalization [0m(Farrar, Straus and Giroux, New York, 1999). 

Quite a lot of Harry Potterโrelated information can be found at http://www.insideharrypotter.com. 

And finally, a brief but illuminating account of the problems that beset Long Term Capital Management in the fall of 1998, is: 

โ MacKenzie, D. Fear in the markets. [3mLondon Review of Books, [0m22(8), 31โ32 (2000).

โโ Dodds, P. S., Muhamad, R., and Watts, D. J. An experimental study of search in global social networks. [3mScience, [0m301, 827โ829 
(2003).
